t: Proverbs 19
Better*pn a poor person who lives with integrity than*ln someone who has deceitful lips and is a fool.
Even*pn zeal is not good without knowledge, and*ln the one who acts hastily sins.
A*pn person’s own foolishness leads him astray, yet*ln his heart rages against the Lord.*s
Wealth*pn attracts many friends, but*ln a poor person is separated from his friend.
A*pn false witness will not go unpunished, and*ln one who utters lies will not escape.
Many*pn seek a ruler’s favor, and*ln everyone is a friend of one who gives gifts.
All*pn the brothers of a poor person hate him; how*ln much more do his friends keep*ln their distance from him! He*ln may pursue them with words, but*ln they are not there.
The*pn one who acquires good sense loves himself; one*ln who safeguards understanding finds success.
A*pn false witness will not go unpunished, and*ln one who utters lies perishes.
Luxury*pn is not appropriate for a fool— how*ln much less for a slave to rule over princes!
A*pn person’s insight gives him patience, and*ln his virtue is to overlook an offense.
A*pn king’s rage is like the roaring of a lion, but*ln his favor is like dew on the grass.
A*pn foolish son is his father’s ruin, and*ln a wife’s nagging is an endless dripping.
A*pn house and wealth are inherited from fathers, but*ln a prudent wife is from the Lord.*s
Laziness*pn induces deep sleep, and*ln a lazy person will go hungry.
The*pn one who keeps commands preserves himself; one*ln who disregards his ways will die.
Kindness*pn to the poor is a loan to the Lord,*s and*ln he will give a reward to the lender.
Discipline*pn your son while there is hope; don’t*ln set your heart on being the cause of his death.
A*pn person with intense anger bears the penalty; if*ln you rescue him, you’ll have to do it again.
Listen*pn to counsel and receive instruction so*ln that you may be wise later in life.
Many*pn plans are in a person’s heart, but*ln the Lord’s*s decree will prevail.
What*pn is desirable in a person is his fidelity; better*ln to be a poor person than a liar.
The*pn fear of the Lord*s leads to life; one*ln will sleep at night without danger.
The*pn slacker buries his hand in the bowl; he*ln doesn’t even bring it back to his mouth!
Strike*pn a mocker, and the inexperienced learn a lesson; rebuke*ln the discerning, and he gains knowledge.
The*pn one who plunders his father and evicts his mother is*ln a disgraceful and shameful son.
If*pn you stop listening to correction, my son, you*ln will stray from the words of knowledge.
A*pn worthless witness mocks justice, and*ln a wicked mouth swallows iniquity.
Judgments*pn are prepared for mockers, and*ln beatings for the backs of fools.
